Hi,
   Yes internal energy can be negative. It's an arbitrary scale based o=
n
a standard.  For example, The standard used by the NIST database is
based=
 on the assuming the enthalpy of elements in their most common
states at 29=
8 K and 1 atm is zero. This means that quite a few species
have negative en=
thalpies and internal energies.
Even standard entropies may have negative v=
alues.  But, that's a more
complicated story.


Best wishes,
Harry Moffat

Hi Cantera users

I have a bit of a problem which puzzles me.=
 With cantera (1.6r3 on
windows and Linux) with python 2.4 when I create a =
gas object at
standard conditions e.g.

>>> gas =3D Can=

K

I get a negative =
internal energy. How come? I didn't think internal
energy could be negative=
, or have I missed something obvious here (like
1. grade thermodynamics)?

=
